bioghist.p: Henry Schreiner Stellwagen (1803-1866) was raised in Philadelphia. In his youth he traveled to Calcutta in an East India merchantman. In 1828 Stellwagen entered the US Navy as a midshipman. He was promoted in 1840 to Lieutenant. His first active service was in Africa helping to control the slave trade. Stellwagen then served under Commodore Perry at the fall of Vera Cruz in 1847. In 1854 he had command of a fleet of surveying vessels which discovered and accurately described a large submarine bank in Massachusetts Bay. It was named Stellwagen Bank. In 1855, Stellwagen was promoted to Commander. In 1861, he helped plan and execute attacks on Forts Hatteras and Clark at Hatteras Inlet. In 1862 he was commissioned Captain. In mid 1863, he was given command of the Mediterranean Squadron and remained there until 1864 aboard the flagship Constellation. Stellwagen retired from the navy in 1865. He died at Cape Island, New Jersey in 1866.

scopecontent.p: Collection of papers documenting Henry Schreiner Stellwagen's service in the United States Navy. Materials include: orders and appointments for Stellwagen; copies of general Navy orders related to uniforms; letter from Secretary of the Navy Gideon Welles informing Stellwagen of his placement of the list of retired officers; letters related to Stellwagen's Naval service; an 1848 report from the Franklin Institute of Science on a patent for a sounding apparatus invented by Lt. Stellwagen; and a patent certificate, 1842, including an illustration of the device. Cartes de visite of naval officers, including: Captain Percival Drayton (flagship Hartford), Rear Admiral David Glasgow Farragut, Colonel William L. Long, Commander George Henry Preble, Rear Admiral S.P. Lee, Commodore A.S. Glisson, and others. Includes several images of European officers and civilians, including General and Governor Tunis, Othman Bey, Italian Vice Admiral Almiraglio Albini, and others. The collection also includes a photograph of the steam and sail powered ships California and Unadilla, and photographs of a trophy and a plaque awarded in 1912 to the Colorado.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
